title: House rejects satellite spectrum licensing bill because of space safety provisions
summary: A bill intended to reform satellite spectrum licensing regulations failed to pass the House July 25 after some members objected to provisions they claimed gave the FCC authority to regulate space safety.

title: Launch roundup: Falcon Heavy to launch largest GEO satellite, Rocket Lab’s Electron to complete 40th flight
summary: The week of July 24 through July 30 will end the month with at least four more launches, focused mostly on increasing the number of Earth-imaging satellites sent to space. Firstly, China will launch a currently unknown payload atop the Chang Zheng 2D. The Earth-imaging satellites include the Singapore government’s latest synthetic aperture radar (SAR) payload launching from India and the first of Capella Space’s Acadia satellites launching from New Zealand with Rocket Lab. Dubbed the “We Love the Nightlife“ mission, it will mark Electron’s 40th launch into space.

title: Spire to devise GNSS-independent aircraft tracking satellites for ESA
summary: A Spire Global-led group has won European Space Agency funds to develop a satellite to demonstrate a civil aviation tracking constellation that would not rely on GPS, or any other global navigation satellite system vulnerable to interference.

title: SpaceX gears up for Falcon Heavy launch
summary: SpaceX is targeting no earlier than Wednesday, July 26th, for the launch of the Jupiter 3/Echostar XXIV communications satellite from Launch Complex...

title: If you’re going to the south pole, go to the south pole
summary: NASA has been planning for years to go to the south pole of the moon, and that is where it should go.

title: Space Force selects vendors for low Earth orbit satellite services
summary: The U.S. Space Force announced July 24 it selected 16 companies that will compete for low Earth orbit satellite services contracts.

title: NASA Sets Coverage for Cargo Launch to International Space Station
summary: NASA and commercial cargo provider Northrop Grumman are targeting 8:31 p.m. EDT, Tuesday, Aug. 1, for the launch of the company’s 19th resupply mission to the International Space Station from the agency’s Wallops Flight Facility in Virginia.

title: NASA selects companies to advance lunar power and other technologies
summary: Companies working on nuclear and solar power systems for the moon are among the winners of NASA awards to advance their technologies for future use by NASA and commercial customers.

title: Space Force to further define details of a ‘commercial space reserve’
summary: The Space Force is moving forward with plans to establish a commercial space reserve to ensure the U.S. military has access to commercial satellite services during conflicts.

title: NASA Partners with American Companies on Key Moon, Exploration Tech
summary: NASA has selected 11 U.S. companies to develop technologies that could support long-term exploration on the Moon and in space for the benefit of all.
